{{Infobox musical artist | name = Moses "Whispering" Smith | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|1|25|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Union Church, Mississippi|Union Church]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1984|4|28|1932|1|25|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[Louisiana]], United States | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Swamp blues]]
[[Louisiana blues]][[Richie Unterberger]], "Louisiana Blues", in V. Bogdanov, C. Woodstra, [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]], eds, ''All Music Guide to the Blues: The Definitive Guide to the Blues'' ([[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]: [[Hal Leonard Corporation|Backbeat Books]], 3rd edn., 2003), ISBN 0-87930-736-6 | occupation = [[Harmonica|Harmonicist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = | label = [[Excello Records|Excello]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Moses "Whispering" Smith''' (January 25, 1932 – April 28, 1984) was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica|harmonicist]] and [[singing|singer]].{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html |title=The 1980s |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} He recorded tracks including "A Thousand Miles from Nowhere" and "Texas Flood", and worked with both [[Lightnin' Slim]] and [[Silas Hogan]]. He was inducted into the Louisiana Blues Hall of Fame. ==Biography== Smith was born in [[Union Church, Mississippi]]. In the 1960s, Smith's [[harmonica]] playing accompanied [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] by [[swamp blues]] notables [[Lightnin' Slim]] and [[Silas Hogan]], before he was able to record some tracks of his own making. At this time he worked alongside the [[Crowley, Louisiana]] based [[record producer]], [[J. D. "Jay" Miller]], and his output was released by [[Excello Records]]. His [[Single (music)|singles]] included "Mean Woman Blues", "I Tried So Hard", and "Don't Leave Me", plus the [[instrumental]] tracks "Live Jive" and "Hound Dog Twist". Although he was a powerful singer, and a straight but unsophisicated harmonica player,{{cite book | first= Gérard | last= Herzhaft | year= 1997 | title= Encyclopedia of the blues | edition= 2nd | publisher= [[University of Arkansas Press]] | location= [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]] | page= 76 | isbn= 1-55728-452-0}} his potential was diminished by his appearance towards the end of the swamp blues period. He recorded his final album for Excello, ''Over Easy'', in 1971.{{cite web |url=http://www.wirz.de/music/smiwhfrm.htm |title=Whispering Smith |publisher=Wirz.de |date=2013-07-25 |accessdate=12 October 2013}} Whispering Smith died in April 1984 in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]], at the age of 52. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Label |- |1971 |''Over Easy'' |[[Blue Horizon]] |}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/over-easy-mw0000860791 |title=Over Easy - Whispering Smith | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} ===Compilation albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Label !Song by Smith |- |1970 |''Louisiana Blues'' |[[Arhoolie Records]] |"On the Dark Road Crying" |- |1989 |''Louisiana Swamp Blues'' |[[Flyright Records]] |"Baby Left Me This Morning" |}{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/arhoofrm.htm|title=Arhoolie Records discography|publisher=Wirz.de|accessdate=2014-01-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/flyrifrm.htm |title=Flyright Records discography|publisher=Wirz.de|accessdate=2014-01-27}} ==See also== *[[List of Swamp blues musicians]] *[[List of Louisiana blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.wirz.de/music/smithwhi.htm Illustrated "Whispering Smith" discography] * {{YouTube|OwY2D0IgVhA|"LIGHTNIN' SLIM & WHISPERING SMITH -
